newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU vets Anglo American stake in Lonrho.
newsitem.headline: EU vets Anglo American stake in Lonrho.

text.p: The European Commission is probing South African mining giant Anglo American Corp's increased stake in Britain's Lonrho Plc, Commission officials said on Tuesday.
The probe arose from the formal notification of the deal for EU clearance and there was little doubt that Anglo American's 28 percent-stake would be given a thorough scrutiny, the sources said.
In April, the Commission banned the merger of Lonrho's and Gencor's platinum interests and warned Anglo American about any plans to replace Gencor in the bid to control Lonrho.

"If ever, and this is a warning, Anglo-American should acquire control of Lonrho, we would have the same problem," European Competition Commissioner Karel Van Miert told a news conference to announce the negative ruling on the deal between Lonrho and Gencor.

Anglo recently swelled its stake in Lonrho to a direct 25.9 percent and an indirect 2.2 percent. The South African mining giant is now the largest shareholder in Lonrho which gives it effective control of the company and its platinum interests.

The Commission sources said the deal was submitted for clearance under the European Union's merger regulation which bans creation or strengthening of a dominant position in the territory of the Union. A notice will soon be published in the EU's Official Journal.

It was under the same rules that the Commission blocked the merger between Impala Platinum, controlled by Gencor, and Lonrho's platinum division on the grounds that the new company and Anglo would share a duopoly of the market with roughly 35 percent each of the world's output.
Anglo American has expressed confidence that the Commission will ultimately clear its stake in Lonrho.
The Commission has one month from the notification date to decide whether to clear the deal or start a four-month in-depth investigation. -- Brussels Office, Amelia Torres 322 2876841
